title: Rugby World Cup news: Scotland coach Gregor Townsend sits out captain Stuart McInally
text:
Scotland have named their side for their final Pool A clash at the Rugby World Cup against Japan in Yokohama - despite the looming threat the game could be cancelled.

Sunday's clash, which is effectively a play-off match for a quarter-final place, may still be called off by World Rugby in the aftermath of Super-Typhoon Hagibis, which is set to hit on Saturday.

Organisers have said they will wait up until six hours before kick off to make their final decision on whether the game should go ahead, but are coming under increasing pressure to ensure the it does.

Scotland head coach Gregor Townsend has named his squad to face Japan on Sunday

TEAM ANNOUNCEMENT



Here is your Scotland team to face Japan in our final #RWC2019 Pool A Test this Sunday! #AsOne pic.twitter.com/RRdIiTOcSs — Scottish Rugby (@Scotlandteam) October 11, 2019

And Scotland have ratcheted it up a notch by naming their starting XV in preparation for playing.

Making 12 changes from the side that thumped Russia 61-0, only Fraser Brown and wingers Darcy Graham and Tommy Seymour start for the second time in four days.

Captain Stuart McInally has been dropped to the bench, with duties being passed to Greig Laidlaw, while Stuart Hogg has been named vice-captain.

Greig Laidlaw will captain Scotland in the absence of Stuart McInally, who is on the bench

Sean Maitland is the most glaring absentee from the squad, with the New Zealand-born winger missing out with a groin injury.

Blair Kinghorn is on the bench after starting against Russia, having missed the first two matches entirely.

In the forwards, Blade Thomson has been given the nod at No 8 ahead of Ryan Wilson, while John Barclay misses out entirely despite his try-scoring performance on Wednesday.

Meanwhile, off the pitch, Scotland are ready to take legal action to ensure the match does go ahead.

Blade Thomson has been given the nod at No 8, with Ryan Wilson named among replacements

Scottish Rugby Union chief executive Mark Dodson says he will not allow Scotland to become the World Cup's 'collateral damage' and told BBC Radio 4's Today Programme on Friday: 'My view is that we're not going to let Scotland be the collateral damage for a decision that was taken in haste.

'I think there's alternative (venues) around Japan. The point to me, we are talking about now is not whether the game will take place on Sunday, that will be a purely meteorological issue.

'The issue will be if it can't take place then we're really, really pressing the point that we need to have to get this game delayed 24 hours later.

SRU chief Mark Dodson says Scotland will not become 'collateral damage' of the World Cup

'We've had consistent dialogue since the last three or four days around this with senior people at World Rugby, but World Rugby seem to be determined to stick to its plan that the match is either played on Sunday or indeed it is cancelled, and to have it cancelled and have our ability to progress from this group put at peril, we believe is absolutely unacceptable.

'World Rugby is pointing us back to the participation agreement. We've had legal opinion - from a leading QC - that challenges World Rugby's interpretation.

'We don't know that (it's too late) - we have to challenge it.'
